It is true that the school witnessed a wave of false bomb threats in that academic year, but according to local news reports, it appears to have occurred in the fall. According to an article published on November 9, 1972, in the Wilmington News Journal, the school received a series of bomb threats over several days, resulting in the evacuation of 1,600 students from the school. The article states that the Board of Education provides "100 dollars as a reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of persons or persons who have made more than 10 bomb threats to secondary school." About a week later, the newspaper reported that three juveniles, all school students, had been arrested by the police and charged with making false bomb threats.
